commentBody: Thanks for some distinctions between "coming out" and "self-identifying."  I'm also thinking that they encode different assumptions about how sexuality works.  If I "come out," I'm revealing a clear and inherent sexual orientation / preference / identity (not sure of the best word here).  If I "self-identify," it is a linguistic act of naming; there is not necessarily a single "core" or "truth" that is being revealed.  Sure, the outcome can be the same, but it sounds like there's more flexibility for change over time in self-identification, because the self is not seen as a solid "essence" that can be unearthed and exposed.  Also, there's a layer of implication that I would "come out" to someone else, while I would "self-identify" (first) to myself, and anyone else who happens to hear about it is lucky though somehow irrelevant to the (f)act of self-identification.
